Now, on Sunday, friends and family have gathered to help the Millers clean up downed trees and the wreckage that remains of the family's gazebo and treehouse. This was the first tornado the couple had experienced while living in their Pleasant Hill home, but both were prepared for the storms.

"We both grew up on farms in Iowa," Chris Miller said. "If it wasn't like right outside your house, you just stood outside and watched it."

The Millers lost power around 5:30 p.m. Saturday and expect to be without power for a couple weeks, as several of the utility poles holding power lines in their neighborhood either snapped or were leveled completely.

MORE: As they clean up, Iowans share harrowing stories of destruction, survival from Saturday's tornadoes and severe weather

"We are very fortunate and very lucky that our house is still livable," Von said. "The neighbors lost their roof, two houses down she lost her whole house. It was on a slab and it's just gone."

While their house took less severe damage, the treehouse destroyed in the tornado held special meaning for the family.

"We'll probably put something out there (to replace it)," Von said. "The sad thing is, when we added onto this house, we had an old two-story garage that was kind of pulling off. Our daughter asked what we were going to do with it.

"My daughter and I tore it down, pulled all the nails out, salvaged all the wood and built a two-story treehouse. And now that's gone. It's kind of sad."

Parts of the treehouse and gazebo were blown onto neighboring property, and pieces of neighbors' property are now in the Millers' yard. - Grace Altenhofen

4:12 p.m. NWS Des Moines says to be prepared for winter weather Sunday night

Peak snowfall will occur between 9 p.m. and 3 a.m. from Sunday night to early Monday morning. "Be prepared for possible slick roads," NWS said in a tweet.

MORE: What is a 'wedge' tornado and did we see one in Iowa on Saturday?

The most amount of snow is predicted to happen in southeast Iowa, although Winterset and Chariton, two of the cities most affected by Saturday's tornadoes and severe weather, are included in the NWS map.

3:45 p.m. Winterset boys basketball plays in the state tournament Tuesday. On Sunday, they were cleaning up tornado damage

When a devastating tornado hit Winterset Saturday, members of the Winterset Huskies boys basketball team sprang to action.

Tuesday at 3:45 p.m., No. 4 seed Winterset (19-5) will play No. 5 seed Marion (19-5) in the Class 3A boys state basketball tournament at Wells Fargo Arena in Des Moines.

Sunday, however, the Huskies were far from the court, at the home of Cecilia Lloyd, 72, who was killed in the tornado.

An overturned Cadillac rested where a three-car garage used to be. Photos, statues, video tapes and other knick-knacks sat scattered across the property Cecilia Lloyd shared with her husband Tom Lloyd, who was seriously injured.

Winterset head coach Josh Henry picked up personal belongings shortly after arriving at about 1:30 p.m. Henry and other Huskies never imagined they’d be working in the mud on a bitterly cold day in Winterset three days before their state tournament appearance.

But at Cecilia Lloyd’s home, life humbled Henry and his players.

“It’s way more than basketball. We preach that to our guys anyway,” Henry said. “This is real life seeing that play out. Picking up clothes and personal belongings, it shows you that life is way more than basketball or any sport.”

The stakes Tuesday at Wells Fargo Arena will be high. Henry and his team want to win. But this is life, he said. That's so, so much more important. Brayden Dinkla, one of Winterset's players, told the Register a cheerleader's house was destroyed, as was the house of an uncle of one of the players.

“We as a society put so much emphasis on sports," Henry said. "But things like this help everyone open their eyes up.”

MORE: See photos and videos of damage from the tornadoes and severe weather that swept through Iowa on Saturday

Senior Blake Bellamy is a forward for Winterset. He met up with Henry and several of his teammates at 1 p.m. to clean up at houses around Winterset.

Like his teammates, Bellamy is excited for Tuesday. When the tornado hit Saturday, he was in Des Moines. Bellamy echoed his coach’s sentiment that this showed the importance of sports as an escape, but that they also have their place.

“At the end of the day basketball is just basketball. This is real life stuff that needs to be done before basketball,” Bellamy said. “Basketball doesn’t come first when stuff like this happens.”

3:20 p.m. Red Haw State Park in Chariton has extensive damage and will be closed for the time being

Iowa DNR spokesperson Tammie Krausman said there was extensive damage to trees, a few beach docks and then campground, where a woman was ultimately killed at Red Haw State Park in Chariton, Iowa.

Two shelters and a storage building are "pretty much demolished," she said.

Krausman said they still don't know the full extent of damage. The park is closed and she doesn't know when it will reopen at this time.

2:53 p.m. Names of 6 people who died from Winterset tornado released

According to Iowa State Patrol Sergeant Alex Dinkla, they are:

Melissa Bazley, 63

Rodney Clark, 64

Cecilia Lloyd, 72

Michael Bolger, 37

Kinlee Bolger, 5

Owen Bolger, 2

There also also six more people being treated for their injuries, according to Dinkla.

2:38 p.m. Carver Road in Winterset is closed; Winterset school bus transporting volunteers to help

Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said Carver Road is closed and that they have a Winterset school bus picking up volunteers and transporting them to clean-up areas to keep traffic off the road.

"Today, as we're talking, people are out there picking up debris, using chainsaws because they wanted to help," Ayala said.

2:31 p.m. Official says warning system worked 'really well'

Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said he thinks the weather warning system in the county worked “really well."

"I know for my agency, my office, we sent out about three or four notifications," he said. "Even when the tornado warning came through, we sent out a quick alert.

"We did our best to make sure everyone was aware of what was going on before the storm and after the storm as well."

2:28 p.m. Official says Winterset tornado affected 52 homes, spanned 13.7 miles

Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said the EF-3 tornado that struck Winterset spanned over 13.7 miles damaged or destroyed 52 homes.

"I cannot express the heroism of the responders that were out there last night and worked tirelessly across the state to make sure that every single person that was missing is accounted for," Ayala said, "and worked to really make sure that we can get up this morning to do the exact same thing again."

2:20 p.m. Gov. Reynolds says FEMA is ready to help after Iowa tornado damage

Reynolds she heard from Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas of the Department of Homeland Security this morning and he had already reached out to FEMA, which stands ready if there’s anything they need to do.

Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said American Red Cross Madison County has an emergency shelter set up at Newbridge Church in Winterset for anyone needing assistance.

2:10 p.m. Gov. Kim Reynolds teared up when talking about volunteers after touring Iowa tornado damage in Winterset

"Lastly before I turn it over, (I want to) just to talk about the number of volunteers; 200-300 Iowans not only from Madison County and Winterset but from communities and towns all across the state that were on the ground the minute it was light and they started helping."

"Over and over the response was 'We’re Iowans. That’s what we do. We show up. We take care of our family. We take care of our neighbors. We take care of our community."

"I'm proud of Iowans and the way that they always step up and respond and I'm so proud of local leaders and the coordination that takes place every time we have an emergency disaster."

2:03 p.m. Kim Reynolds calls the damage in Winterset 'devastating'

During her 2 p.m. press conference following a tour of damage from the Winterset tornado, Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds opened by calling the damage "devastating."

"It was unimaginable the destruction we were able to witness on the brief tour we just went through," she said.

1:31 p.m. Saturday's formation could be a 'wedge' tornado

A tornado that hit Madison County in Iowa Saturday and killed six people there was so wide it could be considered a wedge tornado.

The term is pretty subjective and based on appearances, said National Weather Service meteorologist Alex Krull. There aren't any exact measurements that define a wedge tornado, only that the formation is very large — typically short and wide.

The Register has more information on wedge tornadoes online.

1:17 p.m. Faith Mathews felt the tornado pulling her away as she ran inside

At the end of a particularly hard-hit stretch of Southeast Sixth Avenue in Runnells, a long line of 120-foot high MidAmerican highline wooden power lines were toppled, prohibiting people who wanted to help about six neighbors whose homes and barns were severely damaged in the storm.

Faith Mathews said she and her husband David had just returned home on Saturday around 4:30 p.m. and were assessing the weather when they both heard the wind making a strange sound.

David yelled at Faith from outside the house to get down into the basement.

Faith said she could feel the tornado pulling her away from the house as she made her way down toward the basement. She covered their dog with her body. David covered them both with his.

When they finally were able to get up, their home was completely destroyed.

The tornado tore the roof off the three-bedroom home and crumbled the brick walls. The Mathews’ coffee business, American Pride Roasters, which sells beans at the downtown Des Moines Farmers Market, also was destroyed. A Lance camper the couple purchased last fall sat upside down on the couple’s Corvette. Two Ford pickups also were damaged. The house was uninhabitable.

“You just think this isn’t real,” said Faith Mathews, who is 45. “I don’t know how I feel really. I think I’m still in a lot of shock.”

By noon Sunday, numerous people had reached out to help the neighbors along Southeast Sixth Ave, though many could not get near the homes and farms.

“It’s so amazing how people reach out,” Faith Mathews said. “We’ll rebuild. It’s all we can do.”

In the farm field next to the Mathews home, corn stalks were bent to the ground toward the east, the direction of the tornado. Grain wagons from a five-generation farm a half mile away were tossed around like children’s toys.

The grain wagons belonged to Tim Fritz, who lost his 180-year-old barn, original to the family farm he grew up on, when the tornado tore through from the 8400 block to 9300 block of Southeast Sixth.

Downed trees and other debris also lay in the field. Fritz and his girlfriend Julie were hauling cattle to southwest Iowa when the tornado hit, they said.

At Four Mile Elementary School, members of the Red Cross, the Polk County Sheriff’s Department, Pleasant Hill Fire Department and other volunteers stood by to help families who stopped in infrequently needing help.

But most neighbors who were affected, as well as their family and their friends, were busy cleaning up the widespread damage on their properties as snow was forecast to hit the area by evening. - Lee Rood

1:10 p.m. Professor estimates $1 billion in damages after Iowa tornado, severe weather

Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini told the Associated Press that Saturday's tornadoes and severe weather across Iowa, combined with wind damage as far away as Illinois, likely caused more than $1 billion in damages.

1:02 p.m. 'It was so loud, it was quiet. I don't know how else to describe it.'

Josie Carter and her father Chad Carter rode out the Winterset tornado in the basement of their home on top of a tall hill about a mile northeast of U.S. HWY 169. On Sunday morning, a small army of volunteers helped them clean up what remained of their home.

“It was so loud, it was quiet,” Josie Carter, 17, said. “I don’t know how else to describe it. I could hear it was a big wind storm, then so much was going on. It just went quiet and still. I want to say that was the eye.”

“I just remember the pressure,” Chad Carter added.

They narrowly survived, they said.

“I was able to get to the basement and the door slammed because of the wind, but (my dad) was still at the bottom of the stairs. He didn’t quite get into the basement. So I thought he was gone,” Josie Carter said.

The Carters moved into the home about eight years ago. On Sunday morning, they found a few pictures and keepsakes among the rubble.

“No treasures yet,” Chad Carter said. - Philip Joens

12:54 p.m. Description of a man being inside a Chariton camper that was thrown into the air

The owner of Country Cabins in Chariton, Nick Cattell, told the Register a man was in one of his campers when it was propelled in the air by a tornado Saturday.

12:48 p.m. HyVee offers meals to impacted families

Emergency centers are continuing to serve impacted areas Sunday. In Winterset, the New Bridge Church is open as a shelter. A nearby Casey's also stayed open through the night to help first responders.

In Polk County, Four Mile Elementary has been set up as a temporary hub for the Red Cross. HyVee will be serving free lunches to staff, families and emergency personnel starting at 1 p.m.

The Red Cross has asked for cash donations at this time. They are not in need of clothing or food right now.

12:38 p.m. Kim Reynolds is in Winterset

Iowa's governor is in Winterset to survey the damage from the tornado that killed six and damaged 25-30 homes on Saturday. She is expected to hold a press conference at 2 p.m.

12:25 p.m. 'It’s like God came down, rolled the trailer into a ball and threw it back down to the ground'

Norm Paulsen Sr. said he could see the tornado’s path.

The house across the street with its garage replaced with a pile of rubble, the snapped trees on his property — he imagined that destruction happened before the tornado made a direct hit on Paulsen’s dream, the Soda Pop Saloon.

For over 20 years the saloon had been a place where families in Chariton and beyond would come together, laugh and dance line, two and three step, polka and waltz without alcohol. A place where children could “get their fingers off them damn contraptions,” as Paulsen puts it.

And throughout the years, he said he’s always heard the phrase: “I wish I had something like this in my hometown.” People didn’t think his dream could fly, he said, but it did.

“It’s the neatest place in southern Iowa,” Paulsen, 83, said of his western rustic-meets-retro establishment. Old CDs, guitars, western posters and cowboy hats still don the panels and walls of what’s left of the structure.

But the Soda Pop Saloon wasn’t hit the hardest on his property, which is called the Frontier Trading Post. It stood upright, despite a large swath of its roof blown off. Next door, the family’s antique barn, was destroyed.

And just a little further, trailers, a large Conex cargo container and fishing merchandise propelled from the tornado laid scattered across the family’s 8-acre property, hundreds of feet away from where they should be.

“It’s like God came down, rolled the trailer into a ball and threw it back down to the ground,” said Cindy Reyes, Paulsen’s daughter, of their Diamond Trio trailer discovered upside down in trees, crushed and crumpled.

The Diamond Trio is a country band Paulsen started with his sister, Charlotte, and Reyes – another one of Paulsen’s dreams.

On Sunday, the Paulsen family came together to asses the damage and make sure their loved ones were accounted for. Humor plays a large part in the family’s make up – Norm Paulsen Jr. says he gets his bad jokes from his father – and to cope with the loss, they cracked jokes with one another.

But when Norm Paulsen Sr. drove up to the property, it was quiet.

His brother, Richard Roberts, 67, warned him: “It’s even worse out back – you will never imagine the devastation."

It took a few minutes for Paulsen Sr. to collect himself. But when he did, he sat down in the untouched gift shop of the trading post.

“Where the hell do you even start,” he said.

Then, Paulsen Sr. laughed.

“Looks like the summer opening of the Soda Pop Saloon will be delayed a week or two.”

His family surrounding him laughed, too. - Andrea May Sahouri

11:48 a.m. One fatality, one injury in Chariton

The Department of Natural Resources confirmed that one person has died and another was injured when a tornado swept through Red Haw State Park in Chariton.

"Extensive damage" throughout the campground included "significant" destruction to "the beach area, including the boat docks, the Bait House, beach shelters and a storage building," the department said in a news release.

"The park is currently without power," according to the release. "The public is asked to keep away from the area, so debris clean-up and repairs can be completed."

11:40 a.m. Upcoming Des Moines, Iowa, weather forecast

According to National Weather Service Des Moines, the worst of the severe weather that struck Iowa Saturday and caused destruction in Winterset and Chariton is done.

But tonight the Des Moines area is expected to get rain and snow before 9 p.m., which could affect road conditions in damaged areas. There is also a chance of overnight snow before 7 a.m. Monday morning.

After a clear Tuesday, the forecast shows a chance for more snow Wednesday night.

11:23 a.m. Road closures in Polk County from Iowa tornado

As of this morning, here are the road closures in Polk County:

SE 6th Ave from the 8600 block to the 9200 block is impassable due to power poles crossing the roadway

SE Vandalia from SE 68th St to SE 72nd St.

Powers Drive, south of SE 9th Ave.

SE 72nd St. north of Vandalia

Yellow Banks Park is also closed at this time.

Again, a reception center has been set up at Four Mile Elementary School and will be open until 2 p.m. today.

11:08 a.m. The National Weather Service will conduct storm surveys in three Iowa cities today

National Weather Service Des Moines will be conducting storm surveys today in Winterset, Norwalk and Chariton, the three Iowa cities that were seemingly most affected by the Iowa tornadoes and severe weather Saturday.

The NWS will post its findings as soon as it can. Its initial investigation led to it classifying the Iowa tornado in Winterset as an EF-3, or severe, tornado with wind speeds up to 165 mph.

10:52 a.m. Volunteers should meet at Madison County Chamber of Commerce

Anyone wanting to volunteer to help those affected by the Winterset tornado and severe weather should meet at the Madison County Chamber of Commerce, where you will be bussed to different locations. The county is also looking for help Monday and Tuesday.

10:47 a.m. The Red Cross will be in Iowa on Sunday

The American Red Cross is assisting those affected by Saturday night's tornadoes.

Josh Murray, American Red Cross regional communications director, said Sunday morning that they’re working with local emergency management teams to determine the most urgent needs of those affected by the storms.

“The best way to help right now is through donations to (our) general disaster relief fund,” he said. “That allows us to use the funds as we need them.”

For those wanting to support the Red Cross efforts, donations can be made at redcross.org/donate.

Want to know how else you can help victims of Iowa's Saturday tornadoes and severe weather? We've got a developing story with that info right here.

10:39 a.m. Video of cleanup after Betty Hope's house was destroyed

This was the scene at what once was Betty Hope's house this morning in Winterset.

10:37 a.m. Winterset residents can find help here

The Winterset Community Forum Facebook group has become a destination for people to post resources and offers to help those affected by the tornado that swept through Winterset Saturday, killing six.

One example is that the Iowa Quilt Museum has free entry and will offer "a break or a cup of coffee" today from 12-4 p.m.

10:30 a.m. The Soda Pop Saloon in Chariton was heavily damaged

According to its website, "The Soda Pop Saloon is a western styled soda pop bar with live music, dinner, and dancing - perfect for the whole family. Decked out with western decor and soda pop memories, the Soda Pop Saloon is a delight for all. This year marks our 17th season with over 480 nights of musical entertainment!"

This is what it looks like today, after a tornado swept through Chariton and killed one person Saturday:

Reynolds to tour damage in Winterset

Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds and Lt. Gov. Adam Gregg will visit one of the areas hardest hit by Saturday's storm. According to a news release, they'll be on the ground at noon Sunday in Winterset, where six people were killed and dozens of homes were damaged or destroyed. Following the tour they'll join local officials for a 2 p.m. news conference at the Winterset Fire Department.

Saturday's storm is state's deadliest tornado since Parkersburg in 2008

Saturday's storm killed six people in Madison County, including two children under 5 years old, and one in Lucas County. According to Des Moines Register records, the Winterset tornado was Iowa's deadliest tornado since 2008 when eight people were killed in Parkersburg and New Hartford.

Some of Iowa's deadliest tornadoes:

June 30, 1860: "Camanche tornado" kills 125 people in Hardin, Linn, Jones and Clinton counties, the deadliest disaster in Iowa history.

June 6, 1893: Tornado in Pomeroy kills 71.

June 17, 1882: Tornado hits Grinnell, killing 70.

March 23, 1913: Tornado in Iowa and Nebraska kills 33.

May 3, 1895: Tornado rips through Sioux, Osceola counties, killing 30

May 24, 1895: Tornado kills 19 in Polk, Jasper counties

May 15, 1968: Tornado kills 17 in Oelwein, Charles City, Maynard, Elma

May 25, 2008: Tornado kills eight in Parkersburg and New Hartford.

Oct. 14, 1966: Tornado kills six in Belmond

Sept. 16, 1978: Tornado in Jasper and Poweshiek counties kills six

Sources: Historian George Mills of Des Moines, Vern Tyler of the State Historical Library and Iowa State University Professor John Stanford's book "Tornado."

7 a.m. Sunday: Less than 1,800 without power in central Iowa

There are now fewer than 1,800 MidAmerican Energy customers without power in Iowa. As of 7 a.m. Sunday, 1,779 were without power, including 1,734 in central Iowa.

10:56 p.m. Saturday: Power returning to homes across Des Moines and Iowa

According to MidAmerican Energy, there are now fewer than 6,000 customers without power due to the severe weather and tornadoes that hit Iowa on Saturday.

To be exact, as of 10:56 p.m. Saturday, 5,671 customers were without power, including 4,904 in Des Moines. That's down from 10,559 total and 10,318 without power as of 6:17 p.m.

MORE: Iowans share tales of damage, survival during Winterset tornado: 'It was the scariest thing I've ever experienced'

10:45 p.m. Gov. Reynolds issues disaster proclamation for Madison County

Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds issued a disaster proclamation for Madison County late Saturday night in response to Saturday's tornado and severe weather that killed six in Winterset, including two children younger than 5 years old.

“Our hearts go out to all those affected by the deadly storms that tore through our state today,” Reynolds said in a press release. “Kevin and I join with Iowans in prayer for those that lost their lives and those injured. Our hearts ache during this time, but I know Iowans will step up and come together to help in this time of need — they already are.”

The point of a governor's proclamation is to allow state resources to be utilized in Madison County to assist with response and recovery efforts. Other Iowa counties may be added to the proclamation in the future.

10:18 p.m. Official says Winterset tornado hit 25-30 homes

Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said four adults and two children under the age of 5 were killed Saturday when a tornado struck a neighborhood by Carver Road 3 miles southwest of Winterset at about 4:30 p.m.

Four adults were also injured, three seriously with life threatening injuries, Ayala said. One person with life-threatening injuries was taken to a Des Moines hospital with serious injuries, Ayala said.

The tornado hit about 25 to 30 homes and the fatalities were in different locations, Ayala said. He would not say how many residents live in the area because families were still being notified that people died. After hitting the neighborhood, the tornado continued northeast through Madison County.

“On Carver Road we saw the biggest impact of the tornadoes,” Ayala said. “On both sides there was a big impact to housing. Many people had their houses lost.”

An emergency shelter was set up at New Bridge Church at 1305 W. Jefferson St. in Winterset for anyone needing assistance.

Carver Road is closed Saturday night near the affected area. People were asked to avoid the affected area Saturday night. Volunteers can gather at the Madison County Chamber of Commerce Sunday morning to help clean up.

EMS, firefighters and police officers from around central Iowa responded to search for victims, Ayala said. First responders are not still searching for anyone, Ayala said. Power is still out in some areas, he said.

The tornado will be remembered in Madison County, Ayala said.

“This is the worst that anyone’s seen in quite a long time,” Ayala said. “This will be impactful for many years to come.”

10:12 p.m. One reportedly killed in Chariton, Iowa

WHO TV reporter Dan Winters reported late Saturday night that there is a seventh confirmed death from the severe storm that hit Iowa. The seventh confirmed death happened in Lucas County, in Chariton, Iowa.

The other six deaths happened in Winterset county after a tornado hit the city.

At 5:43 p.m., National Weather Service Des Moines tweeted that a "strong tornado" was "likely moving very close" to the south side of Chariton.

10:03 p.m. Two injured in Polk County after tornado hit Pleasant Hill

Polk County announced in a release late Saturday night that the National Weather Service reported a tornado moved through an area south of Pleasant Hill, which caused damage to several homes, power lines, and trees on Saturday.

There are no known deaths in Polk County from the tornado and only two injuries, according to the release.

There are downed powerlines, standing water and debris blocking roadways.

There is a reception center at Four Mile Elementary in Pleasant Hill for any resident affected by the storm. Red Cross volunteers will be there to help until midnight on Saturday.

9:44 p.m. Madison County sheriff: 'I'm not going to sugarcoat it. It's bad'

Madison County Sheriff Jason Barnes said a single neighborhood 3 miles southwest of Winterset was directly hit by the tornado. He saw the swirl marks in the fields from the tornado as he drove to the scene and said it looked like it had been a wide tornado.

National Weather Service meteorologists will be at the scene Sunday surveying the damage to get an estimate of its path, length on the ground and width.

“It looked like a bomb went off,” Barnes said. “I’m not going to sugarcoat it. It’s bad. Leveled houses, trees. Just unbelievable.”

For days, the NWS warned there could be a chance of severe weather, the first of 2022, coming on the heels of the Dec. 15 derecho which spawned 63 tornadoes in Iowa. Early in the day Saturday, the NWS raised the risk of severe weather to "enhanced" for Des Moines and areas south of Des Moines.

“I knew to be watching it, to be paying attention. I knew it was a possibility,” Barnes said. “Nobody expected it at that level.”

9:30 p.m. The press conference has wrapped up

Register reporter Philip Joens will have more updates coming shortly.

9:12 p.m. Official say 6 people died after tornado hit southwest Winterset

At a news conference happening right now at the Winterset Fire Department, Madison County Emergency Management Director Diogenes Ayala said there were six fatalities, four adults and two children under 5 years old, after a tornado hit southwest of Winterset at 4:30 p.m.

Three adults are also in serious condition and there was one other injury.

An earlier version of this post was incorrect about the ages of the people who died in the storm. Four adults and two children were said to have died.

8:59 p.m. Updates coming from Winterset

A news conference is about to start at the Winterset Fire Department, regarding the tornado that struck the central Iowa city Saturday late afternoon.

WHO TV reported earlier this evening that at least two people were killed when the tornado touched down in Madison County.

8:51 p.m. NWS urges Quad Cities to seek shelter

The severe storm has progressed through Iowa and is now affecting the Quad Cities, where the National Weather Service has urged residents to seek shelter.

The storm is now approaching the Davenport Municipal Airport.

8:21 p.m. NWS classifies Winterset tornado as EF-3, or 'severe'

The National Weather Service Des Moines tweeted Saturday night that, upon initial investigation, it believes the tornado that swept through Winterset as a category 3 tornado on the Enhanced Fujita Scale, which is the third-strongest type of tornado.

An EF-3 tornado is considered "severe" and has winds of 136-165 mph.

8:11 p.m. 'It was over in half a minute'

Mandy Jurgensen was searching a field full of debris near her damaged home southwest of Winterset. Her small red pickup truck was on a ditch about 50 feet from where it had been parked in the driveway.

She said she had been watching TV with her boyfriend "when all of a sudden it got all dark outside." She said her boyfriend told her "That's a tornado" and they ducked to the floor.

"It was over in half a minute," she said.

The house was still standing but a shop on the property was shredded, as were nearby houses and barns. She said she would de staying overnight in a motel in Des Moines.

8:08 p.m. 'There were trees down all over the place'

Stacie Carter stood below a steep ridge crowned by the shattered remnants of her home south of Winterset.

She said she had been on her way to Des Moines with her granddaughter when she got a panicked call from her husband, who told her about the tornado and said she needed to get home as fast as she could.

"It took me about an hour " she said. "There were trees down all over the place."

She said her husband and daughter barely made it to the basement before the walls began collapsing.

"The wind slammed the door shut behind him," Carter said.

Despite the devastation, she said she wasn't worried.

"I've lived here all my life," said Carter, who works at Winterset Memorial Hospital. "There were people down here helping us out right away. That's what we do here. That's Iowa people."

7:55 p.m. NWS reports the storm has passed through central Iowa

It appears the severe weather that included a tornado that swept through Winterset and Norwalk and caused seek-shelter-immediately warnings on Des Moines' south side has passed through central Iowa.

7:52 p.m. Photos of the March 2022 storm

Register photographer Bryon Houlgrave will be out tonight to take photos of damage caused by the severe weather March 5, which included a tornado that swept through Winterset and Norwalk.

Here are his photos, plus others submitted to the Des Moines Register.

7:49 p.m. Emergency shelter set up in Madison County

According to the Madison County Iowa Emergency Management Facebook page, the New Bridge Church has set up a shelter location for those affected by the tornado. The church is located at 1305 W Jefferson St, Winterset, IA 50273

7:35 p.m. Two reportedly killed in Madison County

WHO TV reported that at least two people were killed when a tornado touched down in Madison County Saturday.

Madison County Sheriff Jason Barnes and Winterset Police Chief Ken Burk were not available to confirm the report.

The names of the people killed were not released yet, according to WHO.

7:10 p.m. ‘It was scariest thing I’ve ever experienced’: Madison County flower farm torn up by tornado

When a tornado touched down in Madison County and, the home of Adam and Jenn O’Neal began to creek and snap, they recalled in a live streamed video on their Instagram account after the tornado passed through.

They hunkered down in the basement.

“It was scariest thing I’ve ever experienced. Our ears started popping, it sounded like a vacuum,” Jenn O’Neal said in the video.

Aside from a few broken windows, their home remained intact, they said. But outside, their flower farm was destroyed.

“We don’t have anything left except our lives and our house but I’m grateful for that, and everything else doesn’t matter,” Jenn O’Neal said as she and her husband were standing atop of the foundation of what was once their flower cottage.

In their live stream, the flower farmers and authors of the book “Small Farm Big Dreams” showed their nearly 28,000 Instagram followers what was left of their farm.

The video showed large trees snapped and uprooted, and piles of debris where the family’s greenhouses and barns once stood.

“It just happened — we’re still in shock,” Adam O’Neal said.

“The irony is this gorgeous sunset.”

6:51 p.m. Tight rotation heading toward Ottumwa Airport

National Weather Service Des Moines is now reporting tight rotation heading toward the Ottumwa Airport.

6:42 p.m. Another reported view of the Winterset tornado

6:17 p.m. Power outage in Des Moines following severe weather

MidAmerican Energy is reporting power outages with 10,545 affected customers in the Des Moines area.

Des Moines police confirmed the closure of Southeast 45th Street from Hart Avenue to Army Post Road due to downed power lines. There have been no reports of injuries, according to Sgt. Paul Parizek, the department’s spokesperson.

6:04 p.m. Severe weather damage seen south of Winterset

According to Winterset police, the worst damage from the severe weather (the National Weather Service Des Moines confirmed a tornado in Winterset) in Winterset is near Carver Road, southwest of Winterset.

6:02 p.m. NWS urges Newton to seek immediate shelter

The severe weather is moving toward the northwest side of Newton. The National Weather Service Des Moines is urging Newton to take immediate shelter.

5:52 p.m. Strong rotation spotted over Corydon

5:50 p.m. Severe weather damage seen near Winterset

The National Weather Service Des Moines confirmed earlier this evening that a tornado hit the ground in Winterset and moved to Norwalk.

And here was the tornado seen in Winterset.

5:40 p.m. Strong tornado moving toward Chariton

The National Weather Service Des Moines said a strong tornado will move close to the south side of Chariton soon.

NWS has identified three main areas of concern for tornadoes: Colfax in Jasper County, Chariton and Russell in Lucas County and south of Allerton.

5:25 p.m. Tornado on the ground near Humeston

Another tornado has hit the ground in Iowa.

5:20 p.m. Tornado warning extended; sirens in Des Moines, West Des Moines, Ankeny

The National Weather Service Des Moines said in a tweet the tornado warning for Lucas, Decatur and Wayne is now in effect until 5:30 p.m.

Tornado sirens have gone off four times in Des Moines, and have also been heard in Ankeny. Some residents in Des Moines have reported internet outages and flickering lights.

5:12 p.m. Tornado now on the ground in Norwalk

The tornado has now traveled from Winterset to Norwalk.

5:08 p.m. Des Moines' south side needs to take shelter

The tornado-producing storm has crossed I-35 north of Martensdale, according to the National Weather Service Des Moines.

The storm is now approaching Norwalk and the Des Moines International Airport. NWS Des Moines called the storm "a life threatening situation" and urged Cumming, Norwalk and the south side of Des Moines are encouraged to take shelter immediately.

A new tornado warning has been issued for Lucas, Decatur and Wayne counties, with rotation spotted on the radar near Leon.

4:55 p.m. Tornado on ground in Winterset

National Weather Service Des Moines has confirmed a tornado on the ground in Winterset.

Tornado sirens sounded in the Des Moines area around 4:40 p.m. and the NWS sent an emergency alert sent to phones. In a tweet, NWS Des Moines told the south side of Des Moines to be prepared to take shelter.

"Take shelter now in a basement or an interior room on the lowest floor of a sturdy building," the emergency alert to phones said. "If you are outdoors, in a mobile home, or in a vehicle, move to the closest substantial shelter and protect yourself from flying debris."

4:35 p.m. NWS Des Moines has confirmed a tornado near Corning and Prescott

It's moving toward Winterset, following tornado sightings by storm chasers Saturday afternoon.

A tornado warning is currently in place for Winterset, Orient and East Peru until 5:15 p.m. According to the NWS Des Moines, tornadoes are possible in Des Moines this afternoon and evening.

Severe weather could bring damaging winds, hail and the possibility of tornadoes in Iowa this weekend.

The NWS office in Johnston said the first round of heavy rain and thunderstorms will begin late Friday and continue overnight, with the second round starting around 1 p.m. Saturday and lasting through the evening.

Hail around one inch in diameter is predicted during the second round of storms Saturday, with winds exceeding 60 mph.

"Damaging winds, hail, and isolated tornadoes are all possible as these storms move across the state later this afternoon and evening," NWS Des Moines said in a Saturday morning tweet. "The strongest risk for severe weather comes between 3 p.m. and 8 p.m. for an area extending south and east of the Des Moines metro area."

The storms are expected to end Saturday night, but northern parts of the state may see flooding in the wake of the storm.

"Rainfall from the Saturday storms will runoff into areas rivers and cause within bank rises," NWS Des Moines said in a hazardous weather outlook. "Where river ice remains, particularly over northern Iowa, it is possible ice jams could develop and cause localized flooding."

Wintry mix and snow is possible Sunday night into Monday, with possible minor snow accumulation in parts of the state.

High temperatures this time of year normally are in the low- to mid-40s with lows in the mid-20s. Expect a high of 67 degrees Saturday, with highs of 42 Sunday, 35 Monday and 45 Tuesday.

Grace Altenhofen is a news reporting intern for the Des Moines Register. She can be reached at galtenhofen@registermedia.com or on Twitter @gracealtenhofen.

search_result.title: 2024 Texas general election live updates: See unofficial results.
search_result.text:
Election Day is finally here. On Tuesday, Texas voters will help choose the next U.S. president, a U.S. Senator, and candidates for various federal, state and local offices on the general election ballot.

Follow along for live updates and results for key national, statewide and local races:

12:15 p.m. update: Races called for competitive South Texas seats

Democratic U.S. Rep. Vicente Gonzalez of McAllen won reelection against his Trump-backed challenger, former U.S. Rep. Mayra Flores of Los Indios, by 3 percentage points in the race for District 34.

Next door, Republican U.S. Rep. Monica De La Cruz blew out Democratic opponent Michelle Vallejo by 14 points to win a second term in House District 15.

-- Bayliss Wagner

Austin City Council election results

It remains unclear if incumbent Kirk Watson will avoid a runoff in his bid for a second, consecutive term for mayor of Austin. Unofficial results from Travis, Hays and Williamson counties show Watson has secured 50.01% of the vote — barely above the 50% threshold needed to win the five-way race outright.

While that includes the vast majority of ballots cast, a spokesman for the Travis County Clerk said the office can accept military and overseas ballots through next week. Totals could also change during the certification process.

In case of a runoff, Watson would have to face off against the second-highest vote-getter, community organizer Carmen Llanes Pullido, who received 20.1% of the vote.

District 2

Austin City Council incumbent Vanessa Fuentes, whose District 2 opponent did not actively campaign, secured a second term in a landslide on Tuesday, complete but unofficial results show.

Fuentes received 85.65% of the vote while her opponent, Robert Reynolds, received 14.35%, Travis County election results show.

District 4

Incumbent City Council member José “Chito” Vela, who faced four challengers, won reelection Tuesday with 58.5% of the vote, according to the unofficial final results.

The most promising challenger, community organizer Monica Guzmán, came in second with 27.72% of the vote.

District 6

Krista Laine is leading conservative incumbent District 6 City Council Member Mackenzie Kelly by around 2.5 percentage point, according to unofficial final results from Travis and Williamson counties. The final results have yet to be certified, and the clerk can accept overseas and military ballots until next week.

District 7

Civil rights lawyers Mike Siegel and Gary Bledsoe are headed to a runoff to represent the north Austin district. District 7’s current representative, Leslie Pool, could not seek reelection because of the city’s term limits.

Siegel won 39.83% of the vote and Bledsoe received 19.29% support, but, with four other candidates in the race, no candidate cleared the majority threshold needed to avoid a runoff. They will face off at the ballot box again on Dec. 14.

District 10

Business owner Marc Duchen is barely leading the District 10 race with 50.62% of the vote. His opponent, Ashika Ganguly, received 49.38% support, according to unofficial final results in Travis County. Final results have yet to be certified, and the clerk can accept overseas and military ballots until next week.

-- Ella McCarthy

AISD voters approve higher tax rate

Austin school district voters on Tuesday approved a tax rate election to raise the property tax rate by 9.1 cents to inject another $41 million into the district’s budget at a time when it’s facing a $119 million deficit — an investment school officials say will stave off the most painful cuts.

Voters decisively approved the tax hike with 58% of the 305,254 votes cast, according to complete but unofficial results.

In passing Proposition A, voters agreed to raise their school tax rate from 85.95 cents per $100 of property valuation to 95.05 cents, a cost of about $420 annually for an average-value Austin homeowner.

The higher rate will raise $171 million total, but only $41 million will go to Austin schools. The other $130 million will go to the state as part of a decades-old program called recapture. The program functions as a “Robin Hood,” taking tax revenue from districts that collect more than their state-determined need for education funding and redistributing it to those that collect less in revenue than their state-determined need.

The district has pledged to spend $17.8 million of the new revenue to raise salaries for teachers and other staff members, particularly for those who are mid- to advanced-career level. Another $3 million will go to hiring instructional aids and the rest will be used pay down the district’s deficit.

School board races

In the District 2 school board race, LaRessa Quintana beat out Sarah Ivory with 60.9% of the 20,479 votes, according to complete but unofficial results.

Fernando Lucas de Urioste and Lindsey Stringer will face off in a runoff election for the District 8, at-large seat after no candidate won a majority but whittled down the six-person field of contenders.

De Urioste was the top vote-getter with almost 32.5% of the 200,412 votes cast, according to complete but unofficial results.

Stringer narrowly slid into the runoff with almost 26% of the votes, beating Amy Moore, who got 23.7%. The remaining candidates — Dylan “Sky” MacAdams, Nathaniel Hellman and Nick Franke — received 8.7%, 5.7% and 3.6% of the vote, respectively.

-- Keri Heath

1:55 a.m. update: Democrats fail to flip San Antonio seats in school voucher fight

In close and wildly expensive races, Republicans maintained control of two San Antonio seats that Democrats had sought to flip in the Texas House.

In a 52-48 victory, state Rep. John Lujan, a former sheriff's deputy and firefighter, won a third term representing House District 118. Lujan defeated Kristian Carranza, a Democratic legislative staffer who made abortion rights and public school funding central to her campaign.

Meanwhile, criminal defense attorney Marc LaHood secured a 6 percentage point margin of victory against Laurel Jordan Swift for House District 121, according to the final but unofficial election results. He became the GOP nominee after Abbott helped him oust incumbent Rep. Steve Allison, R-San Antonio, in the primary. Allison, who encountered Abbott's wrath for opposing school vouchers, endorsed Swift.

LaHood also took donations from the Texans for a United Conservative Majority, a political action committee funded by Christian nationalists Tim Dunn and Ferris Wilks.

-- Bayliss Wagner

1:30 a.m. update: GOP nominee Adam Hinojosa ousts state Sen. Morgan LaMantia

In the only competitive race in the Texas Senate, Republican Adam Hinojosa ousted Democratic state Sen. Morgan LaMantia in District 27 in the Rio Grande Valley, according to the final but unofficial results.

“The people of this district have rejected the woke absurdity of the left — open borders, boys playing girls sports, sex change operations, and fiscal insanity," Hinojosa said in a statement declaring victory just before midnight Tuesday.

--Bayliss Wagner

1:15 a.m. update: Voters pick ACC board trustees

Sherri Lynn Taylor has secured the Place 7 seat on the Austin Community College Board of Trustees, a seat left vacant by Barbara Mink, a founding member of the district and current board chair who is retiring after 24 years on the board, according to the complete but unofficial election results from eligible parts of the six counties who elect the seats at-large.

Taylor came out ahead with 57.55% of the vote against ACC alum Cole Wilson, who has campaigned since January and secured endorsements from the Travis County Democratic Party, multiple council members and state senators. Taylor does not have a searchable campaign website or campaign email.

In the race for the Place 9 seat, incumbent Julie Ann Nitsch, another ACC alum who has served on the board since 2016 pushing for holistic student support and resources, was handily ahead of challenger Joseph Sefton, the newly retired ACC chief information officer who ran on a platform of adding a greater tech focused perspective to the board. Nitsch secured 70.6% of the votes, according to the unofficial results.

Incumbent Stephanie Gharakhanian, an attorney who has held the seat since 2018, ran unopposed for the Place 8 seat.

ACC seats are elected at-large. Trustees are tasked with representing the district and meeting the community’s needs. Results are not official until the counties and ACC trustees certify them.

-- Lily Kepner

1:10 a.m. update: US Rep. Henry Cuellar reelected despite indictment

Democratic U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, a 20-year congressional veteran who is considered among the most conservative Democrats in the U.S. House, defeated Republican retired naval officer Jay Furman in a district anchored by the border city of Laredo in South Texas.

Cuellar, a proven vote-getter who was elected to the Texas House eight times before winning his first election to Congress in 2004, was made vulnerable after a federal indictment in May accused him and his wife of accepting $600,000 in bribes and money laundering.

The Justice Department alleges the money came from Azerbaijan’s state-operated oil and gas company. The Cuellars have insisted that they are innocent of the charges, but Furman had run late-campaign ads accusing Cuellar of using his office “to enrich himself and empower cartels.”

-- John C. Moritz

1 a.m. update: Travis County's Proposition A set to pass, final results show

Travis County is poised to become the first county in Texas to help low-income families pay for childcare after voters showed overwhelming support for Proposition A on Tuesday.

The measure, which is set to pass with about 60% of the vote (provisional ballots still need to be counted), calls for a 2.5-cent property tax rate increase to cover the cost of early childhood, after-school and summer care for more than 9,000 children.

Prop A will cost the average county homeowner about $125 more per year in taxes and generate $75 million to fund the effort. It is expected to launch in late 2025 or early 2026, officials have said.

-- Bianca Moreno-Paz

12:15 a.m. update: Lockhart ISD voters approve ACC annexation

Voters in the Lockhart school district approved joining the Austin Community College's taxing district Tuesday night, providing residents with in-district tuition and a path to a permanent ACC facility in the city, according to the final but unofficial election results.

With 24 of 24 precincts reporting, 61.21% of voters supported the annexation and an ad valorem tax, while 38.79% came out against the proposal.

In exchange for a property tax rate of $0.1012 per $100 of property valuation, the Lockhart school district will officially be part of the Riverbat community, with access to all educational resources and in-district tuition, including benefiting from ACC’s free tuition pilot program which launched this year.

The Austin, Del Valle, Elgin, Hays, Leander, Manor and Round Rock school districts are in-district.

The Greater Lockhart for ACC PAC said being annexed into the college district would provide the necessary accessible and affordable educational infrastructure to support the growing workforce opportunities in the region.

The last ACC annexation vote — of Pflugerville — failed in 2018. The last annexation proposal that passed before the Pflugerville vote was in 2010.

The results will not be official until they're certified by ACC board members at a Nov. 14 special meeting.

-- Lily Kepner

11:50 p.m. update: Some Travis County Democrats leave disillusioned with Election Day results

As the clock approached 11 p.m. and the crowds thinned at the Travis County Democratic watch party at the Driskill Hotel in downtown Austin, friends Heather Westmoreland, 47, and Monica Holland, 42, remained in a row of mostly empty chairs watching the MSNBC feed on a small television. The two had arrived together about 7:30 p.m. excited to join the cheering crowds. Their hopes for the night took their first blow when they saw how quickly incumbent Ted Cruz was declared the victor in his Texas U.S. Senate race against Democratic challenger U.S. Rep. Colin Allred.

Then, news networks declared Republican former President Donald Trump had won North Carolina. Their despair grew. The two watched the number of red seats in the U.S. House and Senate widgets on the corner of the TV screen grow and grow.

“I’m honestly getting sick to my stomach. I’m getting flashbacks of the last time,” Westmoreland said as the two prepared to leave the watch party for the night. They were not optimistic.

A transplant from Illinois six years ago and a Cedar Park resident, Westmoreland said she came into Election Day heavily focused on the loss of women’s reproductive protections. But as she sat through the night, she also found herself thinking: “Regardless of who wins, the biggest concern is what’s going to be of our country — with the civil unrest.”

Both women said they see “MAGA supporters” as verbally and physically threatening in their politically diverse neighborhoods of suburban Austin. Their unease with those they view as politically opposite has altered their life decisions for many years. Westmoreland has thrown out previous dreams of moving out to the Texas countryside with her partner and kids, opposed to the idea of moving farther into what she sees as the heartland of those she deeply disagrees with. Holland has lost close friendships with Round Rock neighbors since 2016. The rare conversations that occur, she said, quickly turn into political rambling.

“I believe Trump for what he’s saying. That he’s being very literal,” Holland said. “But so many of his supporters say that’s not true, that he’s just saying that. And that’s what’s scary for me”

Westmoreland nodded in agreement.

“That last thing I want to hear from someone who voted for Trump is them saying, ‘Gosh, I didn’t see that coming.’” She grimaced. Holland did too, nodding. A Democratic Party employee stood in front of the television to announce the end of night’s watch party.

-- Emiliano Gomez

11:40 p.m. update: Texas Court of Criminal Appeals expected to have three new GOP judges

Texas' highest court for criminal matters will have three new Republican judges come January, cementing Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton's effort to remake the court in his image.

Presiding Judge Sharon Keller, who became the first woman elected to the Court of Criminal Appeals in 2000, will be replaced by Dallas state Appeals Court Judge David Schenck. Schenck previously served under Gov. Greg Abbott when Abbott was Texas' attorney general.

Gina Parker, a former city, county and district attorney with no judicial experience, ousted Judge Barbara Hervey in the GOP primary and will take her seat on the bench in January.

Lee Finley, an attorney in private practice who also has not previously served as a judge, will replace Republican Judge Michelle Slaughter. Finley is from Collin County, Paxton's home turf.

As the American-Statesman reported in February, Paxton, a Republican, targeted the GOP incumbents over a 2021 Appeals Court opinion that maintained that the attorney general's office does not have the authority to prosecute voter fraud cases.

-- Bayliss Wagner

11:40 p.m. update: GOP takes US Senate majority, and Texas Sen. John Cornyn wants to take charge

With the Republicans taking control of the U.S. Senate, the spotlight now turns on the Texan who was not on Tuesday's ballot: John Cornyn, the state's senior senator.

Cornyn has been spending much of the election year courting the votes of returning and incoming GOP senators in hopes of becoming the upper chamber's majority leader. Current leader Sen. Mitch McConnell is retiring from the top post but not from the Senate.

Cornyn told reporters last week in Austin that he expects the vote to take place in the next few days or weeks, and that his experience in the GOP leadership under McConnell positions him well to take charge.

"I'm confident our new conservative majority can restore our institution to the essential role it serves in our constitutional republic," Cornyn said in a statement late Tuesday.

-- John C. Moritz

11:20 p.m. update: GOP incumbents on path to keep Texas Supreme Court seats

Republicans on the Texas Supreme Court will hold on to all three seats up for grabs this cycle, with incumbents defeating their Democratic challengers who targeted them over their votes on two major abortion cases.

Justices Jane Bland, Jimmy Blacklock and John Devine each led their opponents by at least 15 percentage points as of 11:20 p.m., with roughly 75% of all votes reported. The victories extend Republicans' unbroken, 28-year winning streak on the state's court of last resort for civil cases.

10:40 p.m. update: Republican Rep. Caroline Harris Davila on path to reelection to Texas House

State Rep. Caroline Harris Davila, R-Round Rock, is poised to comfortably win a second term, as she lead her Democratic opponent Jennie Birkholz by 12 percentage points as of 10:40 p.m. Tuesday. Gov. Greg Abbott endorsed her in the race.

In 2022, she won the seat for House District 52, encompassing Hutto and a small portion of Round Rock, by 10 percentage points.

-- Bayliss Wagner

10:35 p.m. update: Austin Mayor Kirk Watson poised to win reelection, avoid runoff

Incumbent Kirk Watson, the perennial local politician who first served as Austin's mayor more than two decades ago, secured 51.4% support in his bid for reelection during early voting in Travis, Williamson and Hays counties. With 36 of 176 precincts reporting in Travis, his lead weakened slightly to 51.1% but remained safely above the 50% majority threshold needed for victory.

Even before some Election Day results posted, Watson was optimistic.

"It looks to me very much like we're going to prevail in this race, but you can't call an election with just early vote(s),” he told supporters Tuesday night.

-- Ella McCarthy

10 p.m. update: Incumbents in competitive U.S. House races in Texas take early lead against opponents

Early voting totals show the three competitive U.S. House races in Texas, both in the Rio Grande Valley, are still tight, but the chances for flips are getting smaller.

Democratic U.S. Rep. Vicente Gonzalez of McAllen is leading his challenger, former U.S. Rep. Mayra Flores of Los Indios, by four percentage points in the race for District 34. Just over 75% of the vote in that district has been reported.

U.S. Rep. Monica De La Cruz, R-Edinburg, who is seeking a second term, has an eight-point edge against challenger Michelle Vallejo, 54% to 46%, with about 65% of the vote counted.

In District 28, longtime U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, is up 52% to 48% against GOP opponent Jay Furman with roughly 58% of the vote reported. Cuellar is facing a federal indictment over charges that he took foreign bribes.

-- Bayliss Wagner

Austin ISD declares victory on Proposition A; Election Day ballots still being tallied

With early votes counted, Austin school district administrators and board members declared victory Tuesday night on the district's proposed property tax rate increase to raise an additional $41 million in revenue.

Early returns showed almost 59% of people who voted early supported Proposition A, which would raise the school district's property tax rate by 9.1 cents. Travis County is still counting Election Day totals.

A group of district administrators and board members, who gathered for a watch party at Punch Bowl Social on Congress Avenue, erupted in cheers and started chanting, "Prop A! Prop A!"

Superintendent Matias Segura thanked the community, his eyes tearing up. The district, which faces a $119 million budget deficit, will need to cut at least $90 million from its budget over the three years. This increased revenue means the district can stave off the most painful cuts, he said.

"There are things that we were going to have to consider that we're no longer going to have to consider," Segura said.

Board President Arati Singh vowed to spend the additional tax revenue in a way that will benefit students and teachers.

"We are going to spend this money in a way that is strategic, in a way that is going to increase student outcomes, that's going to give our kids the education they deserve," Singh said.

-- Keri Heath

9:45 p.m. update: Austin City Council District 7 race appears headed to runoff

A six-way race to represent District 7 on the Austin City Council is likely headed to a runoff.

Mike Siegel, a civil rights lawyer and former Democratic nominee for congress, secured the most votes by far in early voting — 42%. But he must secure more than 50% of the vote to avoid a runoff but that could prove difficult with five challengers. Texas NAACP President Gary Bledsoe, the second-highest vote getter so far, received nearly 19% of the early vote.

As of 9:42 p.m., the Travis County Clerk had not posted Election Day results.

-- Ella McCarthy

9:20 p.m. update: Three of four Round Rock ISD bond proposals take early favor

Three of four Round Rock measures in a $1 billion bond package appear on track to pass, according to early but incomplete voting totals.

Proposition A is passing with 63.8% of the early votes. This $798.3 million proposal contains facility upgrades, replacements to equipment that is at the end of its life, safety upgrades and additional classrooms.

Proposition B is passing with 60.5% of the early votes. The $125.3 million proposal would upgrade technology. Proposition C, an $8.6 million proposal to upgrade fine arts, is passing with 56.2% of the early votes.

The $65.9 million Proposition D, which would construct a multipurpose athletic field and improve athletic facilities, is failing with 60.2% of voters coming out against the measure during early voting.

-- Keri Heath

9:20 p.m. update: Round Rock school board races show early leaders

In the Round Rock school district, incumbent Estevan "Chuy" Zárate is leading with 59.4% of the early votes against challenger Joshua Escalante in the Place 1 race, incomplete and unofficial results show.

Melissa Ross is leading with 64.7% of the votes against April Guerra for the Place 2 seat.

In Place 7, Mingyuan "Michael" Wei is leading with 67.6% of the early votes against Jim Steele.

-- Keri Heath

9:15 p.m. update: Travis County voters poised to pass Proposition A

Travis County Proposition A, the measure that would raise property taxes to help low-income families pay for childcare, appears poised to pass after receiving overwhelming support during early voting, unofficial and incomplete results show.

About 60% of the voters who weighed in ahead of Election Day supported the measure. Travis County Judge Andy Brown and Precinct 1 County Commissioner Jeff Travillion, who attended an election night watch party hosted by the local Democratic Party, told the American-Statesman they were optimistic. "We hoped that it would pass resoundingly,” Travillion said as the crowd around him cheered and booed the presidential results being aired on TV. He called childcare a “clear pocketbook issue.”

-- Emiliano Gomez and Bianca Moreno-Paz

9:10 p.m. update: Texas House: Republicans favored in competitive seats

Early voting totals are painting a dim picture for Texas Democrats who hoped to flip seats in the state House and hold off the possible passage of a school voucher bill in the next legislative session.

While state Rep. Mihaela Plesa, D-Dallas, is leading her GOP challenger Steve Kinard 52% to 48% in Collin County, according to early voting results, five other competitive races are trending slightly in favor of Republicans.

In San Antonio, state Rep. John Lujan earned 52% of the vote in early unofficial results, while his Democratic opponent Kristian Carranza snagged 48%. Republican Marc LaHood is up by the same margin against Laurel Jordan Swift, according to the unofficial Bexar County early voting results.

Early voting results in three other House seats presently held by Republicans:

Denise Villalobos vs. Solomon Ortiz: 57% to 43% in Nueces County, early voting results show.

State Rep. Angie Chen Button, R-Richardson, vs. Averie Bishop: 54% to 46% in Dallas County, early voting results show.

State Rep. Morgan Meyer, R-University Park, vs. Elizabeth Ginsberg: 59% to 41% in Dallas County, early voting results show.

In addition, former Uvalde mayor Don McLaughlin is poised to flip a seat formerly held by a Democrat in the state House. He led opponent Cecilia Castellano by 40 percentage points as of 8:05 p.m., though Election Day ballots were still being tallied.

-- Bayliss Wagner

9 p.m. update: Fuentes takes commanding lead for District 2 Austin council seat

Austin City Council incumbent Vanessa Fuentes declared victory Tuesday night after taking a commanding lead over her competitor for the District 2 seat anchored in Southeast Austin.

Fuentes received 86% of the early vote, while her competitor Robert Reynolds took in 14% of the 20,670 votes that were cast before Election Day in this race.

In a post on X, Fuentes thanked residents of her district for “entrusting” her with a second term.

“Together, we will keep fighting for good-paying jobs, complete and connected neighborhoods, and high-quality city services that make a difference in people’s lives,” Fuentes tweeted. “The next four years are about what WE can achieve together, building a city that works for everyone.”

Reynolds did not respond to a Statesman request to comment.

-- Skye Seipp

8:50 p.m. update: Rep. Michael McCaul will return to Congress for 11th term

Incumbent Republican U.S. Rep. Michael McCaul of Austin outdistanced his Democratic challenger Theresa Boisseau in the race for the 10th Congressional District.

An inside player in the GOP caucus, McCaul will return to Congress for an 11th term in January. He was besting the Democrat by 19 percentage points, racking up nearly 65% of the vote, according to the incomplete and unofficial returns. Libertarian Jeff Miller was drawing about 2%.

-- John C. Moritz

8:45 p.m. update: 'Our work continues': Travis County DA José Garza poised to win reelection

Travis County District Attorney José Garza appears headed to a landslide victory in his bid for a second term. The Democrat captured 69% of the early vote, according to unofficial and incomplete results. His challenger, Republican Daniel Betts, received 31%. About half of the county's 925,858 registered voters cast ballots early.

In an interview with the American-Statesman shortly after 8 p.m., Garza thanked county residents for their “vote of confidence."

“It means that our work continues,” he said.

That work will include expanding the county’s sexual assault response team, as well as continuing to grow a unit that investigates wrongful convictions. Garza said when he was first elected in 2020, the conviction integrity unit had only one staff member.

"Over the last four years we’ve built a team,” he said. "We’re just getting our sea legs."

-- Skye Seipp and Emiliano Gomez

8:30 p.m. update: Incumbent Kirk Watson takes early lead in five-candidate race for Austin mayor

Incumbent Austin Mayor Kirk Watson has taken an early lead in his bid for reelection with 51.4% of the early vote in Travis, Williamson and Hays counties, according to unofficial vote totals.

No precincts have yet reported Election Day tallies in the three counties, however 52% of registered voters in Travis County cast their ballots early. Watson, who first served as Austin's mayor from 1997-2001, was again elected to the city's highest office in 2022. His mayoral term is shorter term than usual, slated at two years, after Austin voters in 2021 opted to move the mayoral election to be in line with the U.S. presidential race.

Watson is facing four challengers. For a candidate to win the election outright, they'll need to secure more than 50% of the vote or the race will go into a runoff between the top two vote-getters.

Community organizer and executive director of Go Austin/Vamos Austin Carmen Llanes Pulido is in second place with 18.8% support, according to early voting totals in the three counties. Coming in third place is former Austin City Council Member Kathie Tovo with 17% of the vote.

Trailing further behind in early voting numbers are small business owner Jeffery L. Bowen who clinched around 7.9% of the early vote and the former director of Central Texas Interfaith Doug Greco received 4.5%.

-- Ella McCarthy

8:10 p.m. update: Donald Trump wins Texas, CNN and NBC News report

Former President Donald Trump won the general election in Texas for the third time, as well as in Florida and Tennessee, according to NBC News and CNN.

7:50 p.m. update: Kamala Harris, Colin Allred take early leads in Travis County

Presidential nominee Kamala Harris and U.S. Senate nominee Colin Allred, both Democrats, take early leads in Travis County and in the county's immediate neighbors to the north and south, the incomplete and unofficial returns show. Election Day ballots are still being counted.

Statewide, Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump and incumbent U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz were clinging to narrow leads. The early returns showed Allred running slightly ahead of Harris.

As expected, the GOP strength is anchored in rural Texas while the Democrats were riding high in the urban and some suburban centers. A notable exception is Tarrant County, the state's most purple urban/suburban enclave where Trump and Cruz have small leads.

-- John C. Moritz

7:45 p.m. update: Democrats Doggett, Casar sail to reelection

U.S. Rep.s Lloyd Doggett and Greg Casar, both of Austin, cruised to reelection Tuesday.

Doggett, who has been in Congress since 1995, easily defeated Republican Jenny Garcia Sharon and Libertarian Girish Altekar in District 37. Casar won his second term over Republican Steven Wright in District 35.

-- John C. Moritz

7:40 p.m. update: Manor ISD tax rate election gets early boost

The Manor school district's property tax rate election is narrowly pulling ahead with 52.9% of the vote, according to the early but incomplete results.

If voters approve Proposition A, they’d accept a school district property tax rate of $1.0814 per $100 of property valuation for the 2024-25 school year, 3 cents higher than $1.0514 per $100 valuation, which is the rate without the increase. If Proposition A is approved, the district expects to collect an additional $4.8 million in additional revenue.

-- Keri Heath

7:35 p.m. update: Austin ISD Proposition A takes early lead

Almost 59% of early voters approved the Austin school district's Proposition A, which officials said will provide employee raises and cut back the district's $119 million deficit, according to early voting results released by Travis County. About 52% of eligible Travis County voters cast early ballots. Election Day ballots are still being counted.

In the District 2 school board race to replace Ofelia Zapata, LaRessa Quintana has pulled ahead of Sarah Ivory with 60.2% of the early votes.

For the District 8, at-large, seat Fernando Lucas de Urioste is leading the crowded six-candidate race with 33.8% of the early votes. Lindsey Stringer and Amy Moore follow with 25.6% and almost 24% of the early votes, respectively. Nathaniel Hellman, Dylan "Sky" MacAdams and Nick Franke are also running for the seat.

Trustees Lynn Boswell and Kevin Foster are running unopposed for reelection.

-- Keri Heath

7:20 p.m. Early election results show tight US Senate race in Texas

With a smattering of counties, some big and some small, reporting early election results, the race between Republican incumbent U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz and Democratic challenger U.S. Rep. Colin Allred is about even. Keep in mind, the polls have been closed less than 20 minutes as of this update and Election Day votes are still being tallied.

Allred is running comfortably ahead in his home base of Dallas County, as per the incomplete and unofficial returns. In neighboring Tarrant County, narrowly won by President Joe Biden four years ago, Cruz has a slim early lead.

In Williamson County, north of Austin, it's Allred with the slim lead, and he is also carrying Travis and Hays counties, early results show. So far, all of the rural counties reporting numbers show Cruz well ahead.

-- John C. Moritz

5:20 p.m. update: Ken Paxton declines to join other attorneys general in calling for election peace

The National Association of Attorneys General is calling for and orderly election, and post-election, as the country prepares to elect it's 47th president. One state attorney general's name was conspicuously absent from the list of those who signed the open letter.

Texas' own Ken Paxton.

Recall that in the presidential election four years ago, and the weeks that followed, Paxton went to court seeking to nullify the results of the election in four of the battleground states that went for Democrat Joe Biden over incumbent Donald Trump.

Here's what the attorneys general from the other 49 states and two U.S. territories had to say on the subject:

“Regardless of the outcome of Tuesday’s election, we expect that Americans will respond peacefully and we condemn any acts of violence related to the results. A peaceful transfer of power is the highest testament to the rule of law, a tradition that stands at the heart of our nation’s stability. As Attorneys General, we affirm our commitment to protect our communities and uphold the democratic principles we serve."

-- John C. Moritz

4:45 p.m. update: 'I don’t have a voice': Austin voter turned away after missing key deadline

Jeff Dukett thought he had done everything he needed to vote — but he left the Austin Oaks Church polling site without casting a ballot Tuesday afternoon because election workers told him he hadn’t updated his address in time.

To vote in the Nov. 5 election, a voter who moved would have had to update their address with the elections office by Oct. 7. Dukett, who moved from San Marcos to Southwest Austin, updated his address in late October, not realizing the deadline.

“This is why people don’t get out to vote,” Dukett said, fuming. “It’s just frustrating because I know (the presidential race is) going to be close and I don’t have a voice.”

According to the Texas Secretary of State’s website, voters have few options if they miss the deadline to update their address 30 days before Election Day. If the voter still lives in the same city or county, they can return to their old precinct to vote — an option that doesn’t help Dukett, having moved one county to the north.

Texas has a path for people who moved from one county to another to vote a “limited ballot,” which would include only those races that appear on the ballots for both the voter’s old address and their new one. That would include races such as president and U.S. Senate, but not mayor, for instance.

But that option didn’t help Dukett, either: Limited ballots are available only during early voting, not on Election Day.

“I waited all day to do this,” Dukett said, frustrated as he left without voting. “I’ll never vote again.”

-- Bridget Grumet

4:30 p.m. update: Abbott appears bullish on school vouchers, even before polls close

Republican Gov. Greg Abbott aggressively campaigned during the March primaries against several GOP Texas House members who stood in the way of the Legislature last year enacting a school voucher program. And after he helped many of them get defeated, the governor expressed confidence he'd get his way when lawmakers return to Austin for a new legislative session in January.

That prediction is predicated on the outcome of a handful of state House races that will be decided when the votes are tallied Tuesday night. But Abbott's confidence showed no sign of waning even with a few hours left before the polls closed in Texas. His office put out an afternoon advisory that the govenor will hold "a media availability on the importance of passing school choice for all Texas families" in Tyler early Wednesday.

Depending on how the voting goes, look for the governor's confidence level to flow over the brim, or for him to defiantly challenge the House to get with his program.

-- John C. Moritz

4:15 p.m. update: Parents turning out for AISD Proposition A

Some parents who came to Davis Elementary School in Northwest Austin to vote Tuesday decided to support the Austin school district’s proposed 9.1-cent tax rate increase. The district pledged to use the $41 million it will collect in additional revenue to give employees raises and pay down its $119 million deficit.

Joyce Tseng, who has two children and is pregnant with a third child, said she wants her children’s teachers to have higher pay and access to better resources and thus supported Proposition A wholeheartedly.

Amanda Armond didn’t have to think about whether to vote for the tax rate election. Her daughter goes to fifth grade at Davis and she wants to ensure teachers and students have the resources they need, she said.

“If I have to pay more in taxes for the benefit of schools, teachers, what have you, I will, always,” Armond said.

-- Keri Heath

4 p.m. update: Voters in Austin suburbs contribute to changing demographics

Just north of Austin, Williamson County is one of several diverse and rapidly-growing suburban Texas counties that has moved from being safely Republican to purple territory in recent years.

Elected officials from the county are a mix of Republicans and Democrats, unlike those in deep-blue Travis County. And voters there slightly preferred President Joe Biden, a Democrat, in 2020, but they also chose to reelect Republican U.S. Sen. John Cornyn and a number of other GOP candidates that year.

Two residents who are part of that blue shift are Bryon Curtis and Keizhia Carlyle. Both see women’s and abortion rights as critical issues this year.

Law enforcement administrator and Hutto dad Bryon Curtis was emphatic about his opposition to GOP presidential nominee Donald Trump, whom he feels is “racist” and “a horrible person.”

The main reason Curtis voted for Trump's opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, is her stance on abortion rights. “I have daughters,” he said. “I want them to have access to health care.” He also opposes mass deportation.

While knocking on doors for the Democratic presidential nominee in Hutto, Curtis says he met numerous women who said they’re voting for Harris.

“I've had a lot of women go, ‘I used to vote Republican, or my husband votes Republican, but I'm voting for Harris,’” he said. “It's the abortion issue … I think you'll have more women voting Democrat than you did traditionally.”

Keizhia Carlyle said women's rights are at the top of her priorities. She also cited border issues as a top driver for her, saying she feels Republicans' statements about migration through the U.S. southern border exaggerate the problem.

"I just I think they're using (the border) as a hot-topic issue to get voted in, to scare people. ... And I don't think you should go to the polls in fear. You should know the truth and vote your beliefs."

In Hutto, she added, "Jobs aren't being taken. People aren't, like, breaking into my home. ... This fear-mongering on TV and all that, I just feel like it's a lie."

Carlyle, a Black woman, said the candidates' rhetoric on race and ethnicity was a major reason she chose to vote on Tuesday.

"The negative talk about women, people of color, minorities — I'm just tired of hearing the same old thing from Republicans," she said. "It's like minorities don't matter. And I'm just trying to show through my voting that we do matter, and we do have a voice."

Of the election in general, she said, "I'm glad it's going to be over."

-- Bayliss Wagner

3 p.m. update: Why all politics are local for this Texas voter

Leaving the polling place after casting her vote at Deer Creek Elementary School in suburban northwest Travis County, Nikki Cherniak saw nothing to be gained by adding her voice to the almost deafening cacophony that has become the soundtrack to modern national politics.

A retired teacher of 23 years, Cherniack said it was the school board races that motivated her Election Day decision to vote.

"I'm more interested in what's happening in my community than anything else," she said, adding that there's no shortage of opinions in the race for president and the contest for U.S. Senate.

"We need people on the school board who really understand the needs of the children and the teachers."
